data.title: [TypeScript] Renaming a file with a class gives 'Duplicate identifier' error
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a TypeScript file
2. Add a class
3. Save file
4. Rename or move file

``` ts
namespace MyNamespace {

    export class MyClass {

    }

}
```

When you copy the text of the file, delete the file then paste it in a new file the error stays. Running "Reload Typescript" project does not fix the error.

Here is the before file rename:

![duplicatebefore](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1571806/17459907/1e4866b2-5c14-11e6-8206-f35d3cd77c2e.png)

Here is after the file rename:

![duplicateafter](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1571806/17459906/1e484bfa-5c14-11e6-8154-4438fb40fd35.png)

If I restart the editor the error goes away.

data.title: [TypeScript] Highlighting breaks with a number at the end of return type
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: All

When declaring a return type in `typescript` that ends with a number the colors don't displayed properly.

Here is the invalid highlight:

![invalid highlight](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1571806/17459856/3023ed28-5c11-11e6-8a79-9d746883663d.png)

Remove the `2` in the return type, and the highlighting works:

![valid highlight](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1571806/17459855/3023cb0e-5c11-11e6-8035-9e04f0af7cfd.png)

data.title: Consider to use `git ls-files' for file search if possible

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: For quick file lookup in a very large code base under git VCS it is beneficial to use `git ls-files' command. It's fast because it doesn't need to read directory entries to traverse project's structure. It won't show files which are not in git's index, so for completeness this method must be combined with slower recursive file tree walk.

data.body:
I'm wanting to get in to VSCode extension development but I've having a really tough time using some of the APIs without working examples or at least code snippits. I don't see the mapping from the documentation to the code. 

I want to try and use Hovers but I haven't been able to locate any working examples anywhere. Where might I find working examples or code snippits of this and if it doesn't exist can such a thing be added to the documentation?

data.title: VSCode includes components under a non-free license
data.body:
- VSCode Version: git HEAD
- OS Version: Any

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Clone VSCode repository
2. Read ThirdPartyNotices.txt
3. Find the non-free "%% HTML 5.1 W3C Working Draft NOTICES AND INFORMATION BEGIN HERE" section.

All components under this non-free license should be removed from VSCode or placed in a separate directory that can be removed before building without impacting the ability to build VSCode.

1. Open a file with indentation of tabSize 4 and space indentation
2.Change the tabSize in the workspace settings to 2

3 Hit Shift-Alt-F 
Nothing happens. If I increase the indentation on a line and hit Shift-Alt-F it does reformat, but to tabSize 4

data.title: Question: How to change behaviour of commenting out a line?
data.body:
How is the behaviour for commenting out a line determined (`ctrl+/`)?
I'm trying to fix a language extension for fish shell language (`ext install fish`).
The comment string is supposed to start with "#" not "//" which is what is produced when I do `ctrl+/`.

data.title: Make "Toggle Status Bar" a global setting
data.body:
It seems "Toggle Status Bar" is bound to the location from where the editor was opened from, rather than as a _global_ setting.
## To reproduce
- Create a new folder, `cd` into folder, run `code .`.
- Status bar should be visible, use "Toggle Status Bar" to hide it.
- Close editor, relaunch with `code .` from same location. The status bar should not be visible
- `cd ..` then create a different folder, `cd` into the new folder and run `code .`. The status bar should be visible again. I would expect this setting to be applied globally, rather than in this manner.

This happens on Windows 10 for me, haven't checked it in other environments.

data.title: reopenFolders setting ignored on osx
data.body:
- vs code v1.4.1 and v1.5.0 (2016-08-05)
- osx 10.11.6
#### To reproduce
1. Open VSCode and open a project folder in the explorer (and optionally some files)
2. Close window
3. Open VScode
4. No folders or files are open. If the project folder is opened again manually, the files are restored
#### Expected behaviour

Opening vscode restores previously open project folder and files

Was working correctly in v1.2.0 and 1.3.0

User settings of `"window.reopenFolders": "all"` has no effect

See also issue #9428. _Note the expected behaviour in mac land is technically not to quit the app when a window is closed (osx discriminates between closing the window and quitting the app); not sure if that is confusing the reopenFolders setting._ reference: https://discussions.apple.com/thread/3826532?tstart=0, https://support.apple.com/en-ca/HT204005
#### Why it matters

Having to browse for a project directory every time the editor is launched is extremely tedious and every other major editor supports a quick way to enter a project between running instances of the app

data.title: Inconsistent and Faulty `autoClosingPairs` Behavior
data.body:
In F# we have a set of bounding punctuation pairs that can't be implemented properly within the constraints of the current `language-configuration.json` options

``` fsharp
    [ ] , [< >] , [| |] 
    ( ) , (| |) , (* *)
     <@ @> , <@@ @@>
```

The following are the results of testing with a `language-configuration.json` file that only included `"autoClosingPairs":[ ... ]`

``` js
  "autoClosingPairs": [
    ["(|", "|)"],   // fails       
    ["[|", "|]"],   // works
    [ "(*", "*)" ]  // works
  ]
```

There are some hacky workarounds but each one introduces a different kind of undesirable behavior

``` js
  "autoClosingPairs": [
   ["[", "]"],      // works
   ["(", ")"],      // works
   ["(|", "|"],     // fails
   ["[<",">"],      // works
   ["[|", "|"],     // fails
   [ "(*", "*" ],   // fails 
   ["<@", "@>"],    // works 
   ["<@@", "@"]     // fails              
  ]
```

The `<@@ , @` case fails differently than the others which simply refuse to complete.
`|` is representing the cursor in the following example
`<@|` -> `<@|@>` -> `<@@|>` 
the second key input of `@`, it overwrites the `@` that was generated by the completion

This approach creates another issue where if there is already a `[` in the editor and you type `<` next to it, it completes to `[<>`

Inserting a space after the first character works in some instances but not others

``` js
  "autoClosingPairs": [
   ["[ ", "]"],      // fails
   ["( ", ")"],      // works
   ["(|", "|)"],     // fails
   ["[<",">]"],      // works
   ["[|", "|]"],     // works
   [ "(*", "*)" ],   // works
   ["<@ ", "@>"],    // fails 
   ["<@@", "@@>"]    // works              
  ]
```

But even if this were to work in all of these instances it'd still be an undesirable approach since `()` is an operator keyword in F# and more often than not a space following `[` or `(` is undesirable
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro | Version 1607 | OS Build 14393.10

data.title: removed ocaml extensions

data.title: don't auto close on single quote
data.body:
In F# the `'` is prepended to an identifier to indicate it is generic in type and function signatures:

``` fsharp
let fn (x: 'a) (y: 'b) = ...
type Box< 'a, 'b > () = ...
type Inter =
    abstract Op : 'a -> 'b -> 'c
```

It is also common convention to append it to binding names as it is a valid identifier char, e.g. `let x = 10 in let x' = x + 5`. These usages are vastly more common than using `'` to surround a character literal and as such the auto close behavior is incredibly annoying when writing F#.

data.title: Please, split 'references' and 'run test' options in code editor
data.body:
Hi, i think, single option 
    **"editor.referenceInfos": true**
for 'references', 'run test' and 'debug test' is not useful.

What if i need to run test from the vscode, but i very don't like 'references'? 

Please, split these options to something like 
    **"editor.referenceInfos": true**
    **"editor.debuggingCommands": true**

Thank you.

data.title: Zoom is Cmd= only when it should work for Cmd+ also
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Mac 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Press Command+Shift+PlusKey
2. Content does not zoom 

Most/many apps that support zooming in and out do so by 'claiming' accelerators of + and -
In practice however, they also support = and _ to zoom in and out respectively.
VSCode only supports = and -
Effectively, the shift key should be ignored so all of these cases work.

This may actually be what the author was referring to in #7872

data.title: Add a setting to prevent viewlet toggling when using keyboard shortcut

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Right now, the keyboard shortcut for Find Across Files (cmd+shift+F) functions as a toggle (even though the command name is just 'workbench.view.search'). If you are not focused on the search pane, hitting the combo will open it and focus there. Otherwise, it will restore the focus to previous area.

I find this incredibly awkward because I want the keyboard shortcut to always bring me to Search Across Files, rather than sometimes bringing me _away_ from there if that's where my focus already happens to be and I don't notice. Frequently, I assume the focus is in a text pane (the visual distinction is not terribly obvious) and hit cmd+shift+F, and begin typing but because the focus was actually already in the search box, I just ended up toggling back to the editor and entering a bunch of text that I didn't want to enter. It's worse if I happen to have something selected.

It's conceivable that this toggling behavior is helpful to some people sometimes but it would be nice to at least have the option of disabling it. I attempted to override keyboard shortcuts so that cmd+shift+f only worked when: "editorTextFocus" but it had no effect.
